segments.content: **[Why We're Breaking Up with CSS-in-JS](https://dev.to/srmagura/why-were-breaking-up-wiht-css-in-js-4g9b)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Why We're Breaking Up with CSS-in-JS](https://dev.to/srmagura/why-were-breaking-up-wiht-css-in-js-4g9b)**
segments.translated_content: **[为什么我们要放弃CSS-in-JS](https://dev.to/srmagura/why-were-breaking-up-wiht-css-in-js-4g9b)**

segments.content: Sam is a maintainer of Emotion, one of the most popular CSS-in-JS libs. He explains the advantages and disadvantages of CSS-in-JS, with a focus on runtime libraries problems. For his company Spot, the cost of serializing styles was too high. They replaced Emotion by Sass modules (CSS modules + Sass) with a CSS utility system. On Docusaurus, we use CSS modules and I confirm that it is a good no-runtime and relatively simple alternative. DX is not as good but still quite acceptable.
segments.sourceMdx: Sam is a maintainer of Emotion, one of the most popular CSS-in-JS libs. He explains the advantages and disadvantages of CSS-in-JS, with a focus on runtime libraries problems. For his company Spot, the cost of serializing styles was too high. They replaced Emotion by Sass modules (CSS modules + Sass) with a CSS utility system. On Docusaurus, we use CSS modules and I confirm that it is a good no-runtime and relatively simple alternative. DX is not as good but still quite acceptable.
segments.translated_content: Emotion维护者Sam分析了CSS-in-JS的利弊，重点指出运行时库的问题。对其公司Spot而言，样式序列化的成本过高。他们用Sass模块（CSS模块+Sass）和CSS工具系统替代了Emotion。我们在Docusaurus中使用CSS模块，可以证实这是种不错的无运行时替代方案，虽然开发体验稍逊但仍可接受。

segments.content: This article has started many interesting discussions. It has been known for a while that CSS-in-JS libraries with runtime cause performance problems. [Dan Abramov confirms](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1584835028986793984) and [does not want to use any runtime on the new React doc site](https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/5115). Ryan Florence mentions [performance problems with Chakra](https://twitter.com/ryanflorence/status/1582835729360572416), which uses Emotion.

Ryan Florence mentions [performance problems with Chakra](https://twitter.com/ryanflorence/status/1582835729360572416), which uses Emotion.
segments.translated_content: 此文引发广泛讨论。其实CSS-in-JS运行时导致的性能问题早有共识。[Dan Abramov证实](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1584835028986793984)新版React文档站点将[弃用运行时方案](https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/5115)。Ryan Florence提到[Chakra使用Emotion的性能问题](https://twitter.com/ryanflorence/status/1582835729360572416)。

segments.content: Tailwind remains a good alternative. For me, it can be put in the CSS-in-JS no-runtime category, especially in a React context where Tailwind styling is done via JSX. Some question its [maintainability](https://twitter.com/hi__mayank/status/1584261503670448128), but in practice it works quite well.

segments.content: **[Qwik React](https://qwik.builder.io/qwikcity/integrations/react/)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Qwik React](https://qwik.builder.io/qwikcity/integrations/react/)**
segments.translated_content: **[Qwik React](https://qwik.builder.io/qwikcity/integrations/react/)**

segments.content: Qwik is an innovative SPA framework that [avoids performance issues related to client-side hydration](https://www.builder.io/blog/hydration-is-pure-overhead). It can now integrate with React through a `qwikify$()` function to wrap any existing React component. `client:` directives (inspired by Astro) allow to control when the React component will be hydrated with a lot of granularity. The demo integrates Material UI in a Qwik app. See also [this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLH28rDu97I). I think it's a good solution to avoid doing an all-in on this new framework, and try it gradually. We can also keep the cross-platform properties of React, while adopting Qwik to improve performance on the web.

I think it's a good solution to avoid doing an all-in on this new framework, and try it gradually. segments.translated_content: Qwik 是一款创新的单页应用框架，[避免了与客户端水合相关的性能问题](https://www.builder.io/blog/hydration-is-pure-overhead)。现在它可以通过 `qwikify$()` 函数与 React 集成，用于包装任何现有的 React 组件。`client:` 指令（灵感来自 Astro）允许以极高的粒度控制 React 组件的水合时机。该演示将 Material UI 集成到 Qwik 应用中，[详见此视频](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fLH28rDu97I)。我认为这是避免全盘投入这一新框架、逐步尝试的好方案。在保持 React 跨平台特性的同时，也能通过 Qwik 提升 Web 端性能。

segments.content: **[Fully Typed Web Apps](https://www.epicweb.dev/fully-typed-web-apps)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Fully Typed Web Apps](https://www.epicweb.dev/fully-typed-web-apps)**
segments.translated_content: **[全类型化 Web 应用](https://www.epicweb.dev/fully-typed-web-apps)**

segments.content: Kent C. Dodds explains the interest of having end to end type-safety, from the DB to the UI, through the different boundaries: network, localstorage, DB... He talks about validation (schema, type guards), type generation (Prisma) and conventions (Remix). He explains how this experience is possible with Remix, thanks to inference: it is better to use `typeof` than `as`.

He explains how this experience is possible with Remix, thanks to inference: it is better to use `typeof` than `as`.
segments.translated_content: Kent C. Dodds 阐述了实现端到端类型安全的价值——从数据库到用户界面，跨越网络、本地存储、数据库等不同边界。他探讨了验证（模式、类型守卫）、类型生成（Prisma）和约定（Remix），并解释如何通过类型推断在 Remix 中实现这一体验：使用 `typeof` 比 `as` 更可靠。

segments.content: **[Building an interactive WebGL experience in Next.js](https://vercel.com/blog/building-an-interactive-webgl-experience-in-next-js)**
segments.sourceMdx: **[Building an interactive WebGL experience in Next.js](https://vercel.com/blog/building-an-interactive-webgl-experience-in-next-js)**

segments.content: Vercel explains how they created an [impressive immersive signup experience for the Next.js conf](https://nextjs.org/conf), based on React-Three-Fiber. It's still complex to understand without 3D / WebGL / Three.js experience, but the deconstruction in successive steps is interesting and gives an insight into the mindset of doing creative dev.

segments.content:
* 👀 [React Cache API Pull-Request](https://github.com/facebook/react/pull/25506): exposes a new `React.experimental_cache` API
* 📖 [New beta doc - cloneElement](https://twitter.com/dan_abramov/status/1582814754426433537)
* 📦 [Vitest Preview](https://www.vitest-preview.com/): permits to visually debug Vitest tests. Little brother of [Jest Preview](https://www.jest-preview.com/).
* 📦 [Outstatic - A static CMS for Next.js](https://outstatic.com/): new Git-based CMS that integrates nicely with Next.js. Simple user-friendly editor with the ability to upload images.
* 📜 [Netlify - Background and Scheduled API Routes for Next.js](https://www.netlify.com/blog/new-background-scheduled-api-routes-nextjs/): Netlify using its background functions to call Next.js API based on cron expressions.
* 📜 [Cloudflare Pages support for Next.js Edge Runtime](https://blog.cloudflare.com/next-on-pages/): Cloudflare now supports Next.js, only via the `experimental-edge` runtime that can run on Cloudflare Workers (unlike the Node.js runtime). Their solution is based on [Vercel Build Output API](https://vercel.com/blog/build-output-api), which seems to pave the way for better portability of edge-first frameworks between different clouds.
* 📜 [Microsoft - Extending Next.js support in Azure Static Web Apps](https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/apps-on-azure-blog/extending-next-js-support-in-azure-static-web-apps/ba-p/3627975): Azure will now support Next.js SSR (previously: only SSG).
* 📜 [Persist inputs after a form submit in Remix](https://sergiodxa.com/articles/persist-inputs-after-a-form-submit-in-remix): proposes a progressive enhancement solution to keep the values of a form after a submission. 2 solutions: return the values in the Remix action or use the flash session.
* 📜 [Currying Layout Component Patterns in Next.js](https://creativedesignsguru.com/currying-nextjs-layout/): suggest to parametrize the `getLayout` of Next.js to create Layout variants without leading to unmount/remount. Nice trick today, might become less relevant with the upcoming nested layouts support.
* 📜 [Throwing vs. Returning responses in Remix](https://sergiodxa.com/articles/throwing-vs-returning-responses-in-remix)
* 📜 [Lessons learned from moving to Recoil.js](https://kitemaker.co/blog/lessons-learned-from-moving-to-recoil)
* 📜 [Separate API Layers In React Apps](https://profy.dev/article/react-architecture-api-layer)
* 🎥 [Is the new React use hook a footgun?](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ytXM05PVcFU)
* 🎥 [React Advanced London 2022 - Day 1](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1x7mI_xuVVo)
* 🧵 [Lottie vs Rive](https://twitter.com/guidorosso/status/1582086637328031745): Lottie is quite popular in the React ecosystem but its competitor Rive looks much more performant at runtime.
